reviewText: The apparently full length version is available as "Ekstase" (on a no frills DVD).  Don't buy an edited gobbler, with its missing six minutes.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ecstasy is an early sound Czech film (1933) which starred Hedy Keisler (later Hedy LaMarr).  It became famous as one of the first films banned by US Customs from  entry into the US.  The fuss was due to the nude scenes of 15 year old Hedy running though the woodlands without any clothes and one of the earliest film depictions of female orgasm.  I used this film as part of a film history course on Pre-Code motion pictures and how they led to censorship by the film industry. The plot is weak, the acting overblown, the dialogue so sparse that I had to check with the DVD provider as to whether or not I got a defective disc.  I didn't.  BTW, Hedy became much more beautiful as she matured and the studios make-up departments taught her what to do with what she had. In this film she had not yet become the beautiful, shining star that the future held for her.

reviewText: First this is a 1933 black and white. Yes, there is a nude romp by Lamarr . By 1933 standards it was very erotic. You have to like or be curious about early films.

reviewText: Although I found this to be a reasonably priced DVD I was disappointed to find out this IS NOT a full length uncut version of this movie. Obvious disclosure of this should be mandatory when selling a cut movie. The movie, though old, is interesting and would probably rate at least a 4 star if uncut.

reviewText: The story has been tolddifferent ways- eager young wife in an unrewarding marriage, seeks the sensual reward promised of her marriage bed. This telling turns dark toward the end, and finishes on a moralizing note. So, that's not where the interest lies for modern viewers, although it was something outre in the 1930s.There's still plenty worth seeing, though. Although nominally a "talkie", this stands very close to the silent movie tradition it was so close to: the little conversation it features doesn't add a lot. Its visual styling, too, comes across in dramatic chiaroscuro that evokes the German Expressionists. And the star herself, famous under the name Hedy Lamarr, was called the world's most beautiful woman. Without debating the truth of that, I find it fascinating to see how standards and presentation of womanly beauty differ eighty years later. (The fact that Lamarr held a patent on a radio communication technology that underlies so much of today's wireless communication just adds interest - who was that woman?)Of historical interest, but I might not come back to it.-- wiredweird
